case_vignette: An 18-year-old male is seen for a routine physical prior to starting college. He will be moving from Ohio to California, away from his family for the first time. His temperature is 36.8 deg C (98.2 deg F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 122/68 mmHg. BMI is 24. On questioning, he reveals that he has a habit of binge eating during times of stress, particularly during exams. He then feels guilty about his behavior and attempts to compensate by going to the gym, sometimes for 4+ hours per day. He is disturbed by this behavior and feels out of control. He denies ever vomiting as a means of loosing weight.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been experiencing times when I eat a lot all at once, especially when I'm stressed, like during exams, and afterward, I feel really bad about it and try to make up for it by spending a lot of time at the gym, sometimes over 4 hours a day. I also feel like I can't control this behavior.
How long has this behavior been going on?
The case vignette does not specify how long this behavior has been going on.
Has this behavior been present for several months?
I cannot say for certain how many months this has been going on; the information isn't provided.
Understood. Do you experience episodes of feeling an uncontrollable need to eat a large amount of food and then compensate for it through excessive exercise, fasting, or vomiting?
Yes, I do feel an uncontrollable need to eat a lot at once and then compensate with excessive exercise, but I don't try to compensate by fasting or vomiting.
Do these episodes of overeating and compensatory exercising occur at least once a week?
The case vignette does not provide information on how frequently the overeating and compensatory exercising occur.
Is your self-esteem influenced by your body shape and weight?
The case vignette does not mention anything about my self-esteem being influenced by my body shape and weight.
Do you keep your eating habits and feelings about eating a secret from others?
I haven't mentioned anything about keeping my eating habits and feelings a secret from others.
Are you currently taking any medications or receiving any other forms of treatment?
No, I am not currently taking any medications or receiving any other forms of treatment.
Do you have any other symptoms or health issues?
The case vignette does not mention any other symptoms or health issues.
Do you have a family history of eating disorders or other mental health conditions?
The case vignette does not provide information about my family's medical or mental health history.
Final Diagnosis: Binge Eating Disorder (with compensatory excessive exercising)

I've been eating a lot all at once when I'm stressed, especially during exams, and then I feel really guilty and try to make up for it by working out a lot, like more than 4 hours a day sometimes. I feel like I can't control this behavior and it bothers me.
